page.title: 01New York Lincolnshire
page.content: New York is an agricultural area. It is flat ad open. Arable farming is predominant. Light, sandy soil in the north grows Leeks, early potatoes sugar beet and spring barley. Heavier soil in the south grows winter cereals. Land drainage is vitally important. Large drains collect water permeating from higher land to the north of the area. The village of New York was established after the drainage of the fens in 1810 . There are thirty houses within the village boundary. The rest of the population, totalling 230 for the whole area, is scattered around the surrounding farmland. As agriculture has become more mechanised, farms tend to be family run units and no longer provide employment for the majority of local people. However, seasonal work can be found in potato harvesting gangs. New
